description: Master Kubernetes fundamentals including pods, deployments, services, and the core concepts of container orchestration

slides.title: Welcome to Kubernetes
slides.content:
# Kubernetes (K8s) â˜¸ï¸

The industry-standard **container orchestration** platform.

## What you'll learn:
- **Pods** - The smallest deployable unit
- **Deployments** - Managing application replicas
- **Services** - Networking and load balancing
- **Core Concepts** - Architecture and components

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Kubernetes means "helmsman" in Greek, and was developed by Google based on their internal system called Borg!

## Why Kubernetes?

| Problem | K8s Solution |
|---------|--------------|
| Manual container management | Automated orchestration |
| Service discovery | Built-in DNS and load balancing |
| Scaling | Auto-scaling based on metrics |
| Updates | Rolling updates, rollbacks |
| Self-healing | Automatic restarts and rescheduling |

## Docker vs Kubernetes

```
Docker:     Run containers on one machine
Kubernetes: Run containers across clusters
```

Let's explore container orchestration!

slides.title: Getting Started
slides.content:
# Getting Started ğŸš€

## Local Development Options

| Tool | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **minikube** | Local K8s cluster |
| **kind** | K8s in Docker |
| **Docker Desktop** | Built-in K8s |
| **k3s** | Lightweight K8s |

## Installing kubectl

```bash
# macOS
brew install kubectl

# Linux
curl -LO "https://dl.k8s.io/release/$(curl -L -s https://dl.k8s.io/release/stable.txt)/bin/linux/amd64/kubectl"
chmod +x kubectl
sudo mv kubectl /usr/local/bin/

# Verify
kubectl version --client
```

## Starting minikube

```bash
# Install minikube
brew install minikube

# Start cluster
minikube start

# Check status
minikube status

# Access dashboard
minikube dashboard
```

## Basic kubectl Commands

```bash
# View cluster info
kubectl cluster-info

# List nodes
kubectl get nodes

# View all resources
kubectl get all
```

## Pod Characteristics

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Shared Network** | Containers share IP |
| **Shared Storage** | Via volumes |
| **Co-scheduled** | Run on same node |
| **Ephemeral** | Not durable, replaceable |

## Single Container Pod (Common)

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: nginx-pod
spec:
  containers:
    - name: nginx
      image: nginx:latest
```

slides.title: Creating Pods
slides.content:
# Creating Pods ğŸ“

## Imperative (Quick Testing)

```bash
# Run a pod
kubectl run nginx --image=nginx

# Run with port
kubectl run nginx --image=nginx --port=80

# Run and expose
kubectl run nginx --image=nginx --port=80 --expose
```

## Declarative (Recommended)

```yaml
# pod.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: nginx-pod
  labels:
    app: nginx
    env: production
spec:
  containers:
    - name: nginx
      image: nginx:1.25
      ports:
        - containerPort: 80
      resources:
        requests:
          memory: "64Mi"
          cpu: "250m"
        limits:
          memory: "128Mi"
          cpu: "500m"
```

```bash
# Apply the manifest
kubectl apply -f pod.yaml

# View pod
kubectl get pods

# Describe pod
kubectl describe pod nginx-pod

# Delete pod
kubectl delete -f pod.yaml
```

slides.title: Pod Operations
slides.content:
# Working with Pods ğŸ”§

## Viewing Pods

```bash
# List pods
kubectl get pods
kubectl get pods -o wide  # More details

# All namespaces
kubectl get pods -A

# Watch for changes
kubectl get pods -w

# Custom output
kubectl get pods -o json
kubectl get pods -o yaml
```

## Accessing Pods

```bash
# Execute command
kubectl exec nginx-pod -- ls /

# Interactive shell
kubectl exec -it nginx-pod -- bash

# Port forward
kubectl port-forward nginx-pod 8080:80
```

## Logs

```bash
# View logs
kubectl logs nginx-pod

# Follow logs
kubectl logs -f nginx-pod

# Previous container logs
kubectl logs nginx-pod --previous

# Multi-container pod
kubectl logs nginx-pod -c sidecar
```

## Debugging

```bash
# Describe pod
kubectl describe pod nginx-pod

# Get events
kubectl get events --sort-by=.metadata.creationTimestamp

# Debug with ephemeral container
kubectl debug nginx-pod -it --image=busybox
```

slides.title: Creating Deployments
slides.content:
# Deployment Manifest ğŸ“„

```yaml
# deployment.yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: nginx-deployment
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: nginx
          image: nginx:1.25
          ports:
            - containerPort: 80
          resources:
            requests:
              cpu: "100m"
              memory: "128Mi"
            limits:
              cpu: "200m"
              memory: "256Mi"
          readinessProbe:
            httpGet:
              path: /
              port: 80
            initialDelaySeconds: 5
            periodSeconds: 10
          livenessProbe:
            httpGet:
              path: /
              port: 80
            initialDelaySeconds: 15
            periodSeconds: 20
```

```bash
# Apply deployment
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

# View deployments
kubectl get deployments
```

slides.title: Scaling and Updates
slides.content:
# Scaling & Updates ğŸ“ˆ

## Scaling

```bash
# Scale manually
kubectl scale deployment nginx --replicas=5

# Or edit the deployment
kubectl edit deployment nginx

# View scaling
kubectl get pods -w
```

## Rolling Updates

```bash
# Update image
kubectl set image deployment/nginx nginx=nginx:1.26

# View rollout status
kubectl rollout status deployment/nginx

# View rollout history
kubectl rollout history deployment/nginx
```

## Rollback

```bash
# Undo last rollout
kubectl rollout undo deployment/nginx

# Rollback to specific revision
kubectl rollout undo deployment/nginx --to-revision=2
```

## Update Strategy

```yaml
spec:
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxUnavailable: 1  # Max pods unavailable
      maxSurge: 1        # Max extra pods
```

```
Rolling Update Flow:
Pod1(v1) Pod2(v1) Pod3(v1)
Pod1(v2) Pod2(v1) Pod3(v1)  # Start new
Pod1(v2) Pod2(v2) Pod3(v1)  # Continue
Pod1(v2) Pod2(v2) Pod3(v2)  # Complete
```

slides.content:
# Services ğŸ”—

Expose applications running in pods.

## Why Services?

- Pods get new IPs when recreated
- Need stable endpoint for clients
- Load balancing across pods

## Service Types

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **ClusterIP** | Internal only (default) |
| **NodePort** | Expose on node port |
| **LoadBalancer** | Cloud load balancer |
| **ExternalName** | DNS CNAME redirect |

slides.title: Creating Services
slides.content:
# Service Manifests ğŸ“„

## ClusterIP (Default)

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx-service
spec:
  type: ClusterIP
  selector:
    app: nginx
  ports:
    - port: 80        # Service port
      targetPort: 80  # Container port
```

## NodePort

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx-nodeport
spec:
  type: NodePort
  selector:
    app: nginx
  ports:
    - port: 80
      targetPort: 80
      nodePort: 30080  # 30000-32767
```

## LoadBalancer

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx-lb
spec:
  type: LoadBalancer
  selector:
    app: nginx
  ports:
    - port: 80
      targetPort: 80
```

## Quick Commands

```bash
# Expose deployment
kubectl expose deployment nginx --port=80 --type=LoadBalancer

# Get services
kubectl get services

# Describe service
kubectl describe service nginx-service
```

slides.title: ConfigMaps and Secrets
slides.content:
# Configuration ğŸ”§

## ConfigMaps

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: app-config
data:
  DATABASE_URL: "postgres://db:5432/app"
  LOG_LEVEL: "info"
  config.json: |
    {
      "feature": true,
      "maxItems": 100
    }
```

## Using ConfigMaps

```yaml
spec:
  containers:
    - name: app
      image: myapp
      # As environment variables
      envFrom:
        - configMapRef:
            name: app-config
      # Or individual values
      env:
        - name: DB_URL
          valueFrom:
            configMapKeyRef:
              name: app-config
              key: DATABASE_URL
      # As volume
      volumeMounts:
        - name: config
          mountPath: /app/config
  volumes:
    - name: config
      configMap:
        name: app-config
```

## Secrets

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  name: db-secret
type: Opaque
data:
  password: cGFzc3dvcmQxMjM=  # base64 encoded
```

```bash
# Create secret imperatively
kubectl create secret generic db-secret --from-literal=password=secret123
```

slides.title: Namespaces
slides.content:
# Namespaces ğŸ“‚

Virtual clusters within a physical cluster.

## Default Namespaces

| Namespace | Purpose |
|-----------|--------|
| `default` | Default for user resources |
| `kube-system` | System components |
| `kube-public` | Publicly accessible |
| `kube-node-lease` | Node heartbeats |

## Working with Namespaces

```bash
# List namespaces
kubectl get namespaces

# Create namespace
kubectl create namespace development

# Get resources in namespace
kubectl get pods -n development

# Set default namespace
kubectl config set-context --current --namespace=development
```

## Namespace in Manifests

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: production
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: nginx
  namespace: production  # Deploy to specific namespace
spec:
  # ...
```

## Cross-Namespace Communication

```
Service DNS: <service>.<namespace>.svc.cluster.local

Examples:
nginx.default.svc.cluster.local
db.production.svc.cluster.local
```

slides.title: Labels and Selectors
slides.content:
# Labels & Selectors ğŸ·ï¸

## Labels

Key-value pairs attached to objects.

```yaml
metadata:
  name: nginx-pod
  labels:
    app: nginx
    env: production
    tier: frontend
    version: v1.0.0
```

## Selectors

### Equality-Based

```yaml
selector:
  matchLabels:
    app: nginx
    env: production
```

### Set-Based

```yaml
selector:
  matchExpressions:
    - key: env
      operator: In
      values: [production, staging]
    - key: tier
      operator: NotIn
      values: [backend]
```

## Using Labels

```bash
# Filter by label
kubectl get pods -l app=nginx
kubectl get pods -l 'env in (prod,staging)'
kubectl get pods -l app=nginx,env=production

# Add label
kubectl label pods nginx-pod team=frontend

# Remove label
kubectl label pods nginx-pod team-

# Update label
kubectl label pods nginx-pod env=staging --overwrite
```

## Service Selection

```yaml
# Service selects pods with matching labels
spec:
  selector:
    app: nginx
    tier: frontend
```

slides.title: Full Application Example
slides.content:
# Complete Application ğŸŒ

```yaml
# namespace.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: myapp
---
# configmap.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: app-config
  namespace: myapp
data:
  NODE_ENV: production
---
# deployment.yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: web
  namespace: myapp
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: web
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: web
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: web
          image: myapp:1.0
          ports:
            - containerPort: 3000
          envFrom:
            - configMapRef:
                name: app-config
---
# service.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: web
  namespace: myapp
spec:
  type: LoadBalancer
  selector:
    app: web
  ports:
    - port: 80
      targetPort: 3000
```

```bash
kubectl apply -f .
```
